Any chance possible I love to poke my fingers in big corporations eyes. with all other coffee makers people have found a way to give you cheaper versions of the coffee pods or allow you to create your own. This Nespresso “best seller” selection has three different intensity coffee capsules for VertuoLine machines only. This includes 10 each of Stormio (intensity 8), Odacio (intensity 7) and Melozio (6 intensity) that brew larger 7.8 oz cups of coffee rather than the short espresso shots. It’s a good assortment of coffee that’s all rich and flavorful but varies in intensity.

Stormio is a bold, dark roast coffee that’s rich and flavorful. It tastes like a good French Roast that’s strong and rich enough to make a satisfying Café Au Lait (coffee with hot milk) that’s a little smoky but not charred or burnt tasting. Stormio is a pleasing medium bodied coffee with thick foam from the brewing process. It’s lightly acidic and a touch bitter in an enjoyable way. I enjoy Stormio a lot. 5 stars.

Odacio is a blend of light roasted Ethiopian beans and long roasted Nicaraguan beans. It’s rather dark and bold, but also lively. It has a full bodied mouthfeel as it’s thick and creamy. It’s flavorful with cereal notes and lighter fruity notes. This coffee doesn’t taste sweet like my favorite dark roasts that have chocolate or caramel notes, but milk and sugar bring out some sweetness and Odacio is robust and satisfying. 4.5 stars.

Melozio is more of a medium roast that tastes rich and flavorful but still mellow. It’s not too weak or too intense. I’d describe it as medium bodied as it’s not watery or thin. It’s a smooth and balanced coffee that I prefer with milk and sugar to bring out the flavor and sweeter notes, though I drink all my coffee with milk and sugar (or other sweetener). Being less intense, Melozio is a pleasant surprise as I thought it might be too weak for me. 5 stars. Overall, an enjoyable assortment of quality coffee capsules. 5 stars.

This medium to dark roast variety pack of coffees is impressive. The numbers corresponding to the strength on the coffees' strength is very accurate to me. The flavors are very rich and deep, with a delightful aroma that fills the kitchen while they are brewing. The darkest one, Stormio, reminds me a bit of some Cuban coffee I had years ago. I had to sip on that one, because it was much stronger than what I'm used to. However, it was good, but it's not a flavor I would drink daily because it is so dark and strong and for me, one to be sipped and savored.

The other two flavors were easier to enjoy, because the strengths and darkness were more familiar to me. I enjoyed trying to discern the different "notes" in each. The quality of all 3 flavors felt very high-end to me, much nicer than the typical coffees that I drink daily on a regular basis.

Comparing the quality and flavor of the Nespresso to the other major competing brand, the Nespresso wins hands-down in my opinion. However, it's also more costly than that brand, so that's a definite consideration for me. For those who go out and buy their coffee at coffee shops and are wanting the same (or better) quality and flavor of coffee at home, this is a definite cost-effective and richly flavorful option to consider.
